prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Dense Gas Tracers - NGC 3351
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observations of dense gas tracers (HCN, HCO+, CS) plus continuum and additional lines in the central 3 kpc of NGC 3351.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We target high critical density tracers (HCN, HCO+, CS) with secondary science goals of probing additional diagnostic lines (e.g., SiO, C2H) and the continuum.
SPECTRAL SETUP: We configure the correlator to cover our three high critical density tracers (HCN, HCO+, CS), a host of additional lines (including SiO, C2H), and the maximum bandwidth to sample the free-free continuum.
RESOLUTION: Our science focuses on comparison to multiwavelength data with PSF ~ 5-6" and faint, unexplored lines. Both argue for the most compact configuration and maximum surface brightness. Accordingly, we target 4.1" resolution. This is still 200 pc at the distance of our targets (picked for their proximity), giving us the good spatial resolution that we aim for.
SENSITIVITY: We target our sensitivity to detect heavily molecular regions (Sigma >~ 80 Msun/pc2), assuming a typical line width of 25 km/s, reasonable for a galaxy disk (the very central points will be higher). For an HCN-to-CO ratio of 1-to-20 (see our literature compilation in Figure 1) this motivates 7 mK as a target sensitivity for HCN. We expect HCO+ and CS to be comparable (and achieve extra integration on CS in our other science goal.)
ANGULAR SCALE: We expect emission to be relatively clumpy and know that the sources exhibit strong velocity gradients (from previous CO mapping). We expect angular scales <~ 10-20" within an individual channel map. Given the exploratory nature of the observation, we consider requesting the ACA inappropriate.
DATA RATE: Surveying many lines and the continuum unavoidably leads to high data rate with the payoff of a very rich data set. We have set spectral averaging to 2 for all windows, accepting a small degradation of spectral resolution to fall in the acceptable range.

SENSITIVITY: We target our sensitivity to detect heavily molecular regions (Sigma >~ 80 Msun/pc2), assuming a typical line width of 25 km/s, reasonable for a galaxy disk (the very central points will be higher). prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Optically Thin Tracers - NGC 3351
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observations of optically thinner CO lines (13CO, C18O), dense gas tracer CS, continuum, and other lines.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We target optically thin(ner) molecular gas tracers (13CO, C18O, C17O) and the high critical density tracer CS (for additional integration time combined with the other science goal).
SPECTRAL SETUP: We configure the correlator to cover our two main molecular gas column density tracers (13CO and C18O), the fainter C17O, the high critical density line CS (to improve the sensitivity further), and the maximum bandwidth to sample the free-free continuum.
RESOLUTION: Our science focuses on comparison to the dense gas tracers observed in the other science goals and multiwavelength data with PSF ~ 5-6". We also include faint, unexplored lines. This all argues for the most compact configuration and maximum surface brightness. Accordingly, we target 3.4" resolution. This is still ~200 pc at the distance of our targets (picked for their proximity), giving us the good spatial resolution that we aim for.
SENSITIVITY: We target our sensitivity to detect heavily molecular regions (Sigma >~ 80 Msun/pc2), assuming a typical line width of 25 km/s, reasonable for a galaxy disk (the very central points will be higher). For a 13CO-to-12CO ratio of 1-to-10 (conservative) we can achieve S/N 7 with a line-averaged sensitivity of 10 mK. This is our driving sensitivity; we will detect C18O in the brighter central regions and the CS integration will contribute to the dense gas tracer science goal.
ANGULAR SCALE: We expect emission to be relatively clumpy and know that the sources exhibit strong velocity gradients (from previous CO mapping). We expect angular scales <~ 10-20" within an individual channel map.
DATA RATE: Surveying many lines and the continuum unavoidably leads to high data rate with the payoff of a very rich data set. We have set spectral averaging to 2 for all windows, accepting a small degradation of spectral resolution to fall in the acceptable range.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to test the hypothesis that the dense gas fraction regulates the star formation rate (SFR) by using ALMA to make resolved “dense gas maps” of a carefully selected sample of galaxies. Several theories identify the fraction of dense molecular gas as the key factor that sets the SFR per unit H2. We will test this by correlating observable tracers of dense gas fraction – e.g., HCN/13CO – with SFR/H2 across the central 6 kpc of four nearby galaxies. Our targets capture both the spread in SFR/H2 among local galaxies and the contrast between nuclear starbursts and more quiescent disk star formation. They are also close enough we achieve both high brightness sensitivity and good physical resolution. They also have the data needed estimate the SFR and key galactic and ISM properties; only information on gas density is missing. ALMA alone can image high critical density (HCN, HCO+, CS) and optically thinner (13CO, C18O) tracers in normal galaxies at high resolution. With such data for a meaningful sample, we will build the next major benchmark for theories of star formation in galaxies, testing the role of dense gas in star formation and the conditions for dense gas formation.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: North American ALMA Science Center, National Radio Astronomy Observatory
